summary: angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) contains a single HEMGH zinc-dependent catalytic site. it degrades the vasoconstrictor angiotensin (Ang) II to the vasodilator Ang-(1-7). ACE2 gene knockout mice develop accelerated Ang II-mediated glomerulosclerosis [5] and are more susceptible to kidney injury in the type 1 diabetes. ectodomain shedding of soluble forms of ACE2 has been reported to occur in human embryonic kidney (HEK) cells and airway epithelial cells. ectodomain shedding of soluble forms of ACE2 has been reported to occur in human embryonic kidney (HEK) cells and airway epithelial cells mediated by the enzyme tumor necrosis factor (TNF)- convertase (ADAM17) ACE2 fragments shed from PT cells have not been characterized with regards to possible cleavage sites within ACE2. the aim of this study was to first determine if ACE2 is shed from primary cultures of mouse PT cells. the effect of high D-glucose or Ang II on ACE2 ectodomain shedding was examined. the pellet was gassed with 95% O2-5% CO2 for 30 min at 37°C. after collagenase digestion, the cortical suspension was strained through a 250 m brass sieve and centrifuged at 1500 g for 1 min. the final pellet was suspended in culture medium and centrifuged to remove the Percoll solution. cells were incubated for 24–72 hrs with varying concentrations of Ang II (1010–107 M), Ang II (1010–107 M), high levels of D-glucose (25 mM), or L-glucose (25 mM) after 24 h, cells were attached to the culture dishes, and switched to a defined serum-free medium, with glucose concentration 7.8 mM. after 5 days, cells reached 70% confluence and had a typical epi PT cells derived from wild-type mice were transfected with a human ACE2 expression vector (HA-hACE2) one day prior to transfection, subconfluent PT cells (50–70%) were placed in defined medium without antibiotics. ACE2 activity or protein expression in cell lysates and culture medium was assayed. ACE2 activity in cell culture media was measured using a commercially available synthetic fluorogenic substrate for ACE2 (Mca-Ala-Pro-Lys(Dnp)-OH) for all experiments, media was first centrifuged at 9300 g for 5 min at 4°C to remove dead cells and cellular debris. the linear range of detection for mouse recombinant ACE2 was between 1.56–50 ng/ml (R2 = 0.9976, p0.001) further experiments determined that using this assay, ACE2 activity in media samples was linear for at least 24 hrs of incubation with the fluorogenic substrate. ACE2 immunoblot assays Cell culture medium was removed from the dish. the concentrate (25 l) was then prepared in a buffer consisting of 31.3 mM Tris-HCl (pH 6.8), 1% wt/vol SDS, 10% glycerol, 50 mM DTT, and 0.025% wt/vol bromophenol blue. samples were denatured in 0.5% SDS, 40 mM DTT at 100°C for 10 min. after cooling to room temperature, the samples were incubated in 50 mM sodium phosphate (pH 7.5), 1% NP-40 (vol/vol) and 1000 U PNGase F at 37°C for 3 hrs. the polypeptide bands matching those identified on immunoblots were excised and destained. the resulting peptide extracts were purified by ZipTip (Milllipore) the resulting peptide extracts were resuspended in 0.1% formic acid. ACE2 activity in cell culture media and membrane fractions was measured using a commercially available synthetic fluorogenic substrate for ACE2. MLN-4760 consistently caused at least 95% inhibition of ACE2 activity in conditioned media samples. samples were protected from light and incubated for 16 hrs on a plate shaker at room temperature. protein from the supernatant (25 g) was used to determine ADAM17 activity. a standard curve was generated for the assay using recombinant human ADAM17 provided with the kit. the amount of ADAM17 was reported as ng/g protein. samples were denatured in 0.5% SDS, 40 mM DTT at 100°C for 10 min. after cooling to room temperature, the samples were incubated in 50 mM sodium phosphate (pH 7.5), 1% NP-40 (vol/vol) and 1000 U PNGase F at 37°C for 3 hrs. deglycosylated immunoprecipitated ACE2 polypeptides were separated on 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gels. they were subjected to silver staining using silver staining kit (Invitrogen) the polypeptide bands matching those identified on immunoblots were excised and destained. MS scans were acquired in FTMS mode at a resolution setting of 60,000. MS2 scans were acquired in ion trap CID mode using data-dependent acquisition of the top 5 ions from each MS scan. immunoblot analysis revealed 2 fragments for ACE2 at 90 kDa and 70 kDa. ACE2 was not detected by immunoblot in either cell lysates or media from untransfected PT cells derived from ACE2 gene KO mice. Lane 5+ shows a reduction in size of ACE2 in mouse cortex from 100 kDa to 85 kDa after treatment with the PNGase F. mass spectrometry identified peptides matched with mouse ACE2 sequence. the overall matched sequences cover 32% of mouse ACE2 sequences. the overall matched sequences cover 32% of mouse ACE2 sequences. in 1 of 6 experiments, LC-MS/MS analysis detected a C-terminal Lys619 (a tryptic cleavage site), corresponding to an ACE2 fragment with predicted molecular mass of 69.6 kDa. for this fragment, the cleavage site could lie between Lys619 and Arg644. alternative proteases (chymotrypsin and glutamyl endopeptidase) were used, but peptid the detected b and y ions are consistent with the peptide sequence shown on the top part of the panel. ACE2 is a type 1 integral membrane protein with a catalytically active ectodomain, which can be shed from the cell surface and retain its activity in the extracellular space. ACE2 is a type 1 integral membrane protein with a catalytically active ectodomain, which can be shed from the cell surface. ACE2 was detected as a protein of 100 kDa by immunoblot. in concentrated media from mouse PT cells, immunoblot analysis revealed 2 fragments for ACE2 at 90 kDa and 70 kDa. ACE2 was not detected by immunoblot in either cell lysates or media. immunoblot analysis of ACE2 protein in media and cell lysates from mouse PT cells. Lane 1 shows two bands in the media for human ACE2 in transfected cells. deglycosylation and LC-MS/MS analysis of mouse ACE2 fragments Cell media was incubated with the enzyme PNGase F. in PT cell lysates full-length ACE2 decreased in size from 100 kDa to 85 kDa with deglycosylation. in mouse kidney cortex lysates, the size of ACE2 was reduced from 100 kDa to 85 kDa. Lanes 1+ and 2+ show a reduction in the sizes of ACE2 in media fractions to 75 kDa and 60 kDa for mouse ACE2 and 80 kDa and 65 kDa for human ACE2 respectively. LC-MS/MS analysis of the immunoprecipitated 75 kDa fragment from 3 separate experiments revealed ACE2 peptides with the C-terminus as Arg705. mass spectrometry identified peptides matched with mouse ACE2 sequence. peptides matched with mouse ACE2 precursor in database are underlined. overall matched sequences cover 32% of mouse ACE2 sequences. the cleavage site for this ACE2 fragment is therefore predicted to be located at or C-terminal to Arg577 and could occur before Lys596, the next tryptic cleavage site. alternative proteases (chymotrypsin and glutamyl endopeptidase) were used, but peptides representing the region of interest between Arg577 and Lys596 were not identified. the b and y ions result from the cleavage of peptide bonds and correspond to N-terminal and C-terminal fragments of the peptide, respectively. the detected ions are consistent with the peptide sequence shown on the top part of the panel. effects of Ang II, high D-glucose and ADAM17 on ACE2 shedding. lower concentrations of Ang II (1010–108 M) had no significant effect on ACE2 activity in the cell media. incubation of cells in high concentrations of D-glucose (25 mM) had no effect on ACE2 activity in the media. addition of D-glucose (25 mM) to media without cell incubation had no effect on ACE2 activity in the cell membrane fraction. TAPI-1 caused a dose-dependent inhibition of high D-glucose-induced ACE2 shedding. TAPI-1 (105 M) also partly inhibited the small but significant increase in ACE2 activity in the media induced by Ang II. mouse PT cells were incubated for 72 hrs with Ang II (105 M) in the presence or absence of TAPI-1 (105 M) mice were incubated for 72 hrs in high D-glucose (D-G, 25 mM) media in the presence or absence of TAPI-2. mouse PT cells were incubated for 72 hrs in high D-glucose (25 mM) cells were incubated for 72(107 M) or in high D-glucose (D-G, 25 mM) media. shedding of ACE2 fragments was evident in unconcentrated media from unstimulated mouse PT cells after 72 hrs in culture. LC-MS/MS analyses showed a tryptic fragment with C-terminus as Arg577, consistent with the fragment isolated in normal (7.8 mM) glucose media. one out of 5 analyses revealed an ACE2 fragment with C-terminus as Lys619. Discussion The present studies are first to demonstrate shedding of active fragments of ACE2 from kidney PT cells. high glucose, and to a lesser extent Ang II, stimulate ACE2 release from PT cells. inhibition of ADAM17 blocked glucose-stimulated shedding of ACE2 and partly inhibited Ang II-induced shedding. ACE2 is an 805-amino acid type I transmembrane glycoprotein. ACE2 is constitutively shed from mouse PT cells derived from ACE2 KO mice. ACE2 is a transmembrane metalloproteinase, which acts as a “sheddase” and cleaves cell surface proteins, including tumour necrosis factor-, the type II interleukin-1 receptor, and transforming growth factor-. in ACE2-transfected HEK293 cells, basal shedding of ACE2 was not significantly affected by either TAPI-1 or GM6001. TAPI-1 completely blocked high glucose-stimulated shedding of ACE2 from PT cells, and caused a partial inhibition of Ang II-stimulated ACE2 shedding from PT cells. we did not determine the differential enzymatic activity of the fragments. the presence of the ACE2 ectodomain in each sequence predicts retention of ACE2 activity. ACE2 fragments of human ACE2 at 80 kDa and 70 kDa each retained equivalent ACE2 activity. Arg705 was identified as the C-terminal amino acid for the shorter 60 kDa deglycosylated ACE2 fragment in both unstimulated and stimulated PT cells. a putative cleavage site for ADAM17-mediated shedding was identified at the bond Arg708-Ser709 in human ACE2. a mutation of Leu584 in human ACE2 to Ala584 prevents shedding. this suggests this represents a sheddase “recognition motif”. the significance of this finding is uncertain, although this peptide could represent an additional fragment of ACE2 constitutively shed. the effect of Ang II on ACE2 shedding was relatively minor. increases in luminal ACE2 activity occur in the diabetic kidney. ectodomain shedding of ACE has been shown to occur in polarized renal epithelial cells. primary cultures of mouse PT cells were incubated for 72 hrs with Ang II (1010–107 M) PT cells were incubated for 72 hrs with Ang II (1010–107 M) p0.05 vs C, n = 4–10.
